Award.AwardTitle: PARTICLE AND QUANTUM FIELD THEORY INVESTIGATIONS
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors S. Dubovskiy, G. Dvali, G. Gabadadze, M. Porrati and A. Sirlin at New York University.

This research project involves a number of interrelated topics aiming to answer fundamental questions in theoretical physics. Chief among them: how can experimentalists distinguish the signals of new physics in the Large Hadron Collider era? What is the correct description of black holes in the yet-to-be-completed theory of quantum gravity? More generally, what is indeed the correct description of quantum gravity? How is it related to the description of all other theories of elementary particles? What can happen if the quantum carrying the gravitational force, the graviton, has a mass, instead of moving at the speed of light? Can the graviton actually move faster than light? Is this necessarily an unresolvable problem associated with a massive gravity theory? How do fundamental particles of high spin interact with themselves and with other, "normal" elementary particles? As part of this project, these researchers will work towards solving these problems, both in parallel and in collaboration.

There are also significant broader impacts are germane to this project. All of the senior investigators conduct their research in close collaboration with graduate students and postdocs, thereby providing essential training to junior physicists beginning research. They will also give public lectures on their research results, as they did in the past, not only in the USA but also in Germany, Georgia, Italy, etc. They have already developed new courses and curricula based on their research results, and will continue to do so as part of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The work of Porrati explored the uncharted territory of quantum gravity, the branch of theoretical physics that strives to unite quantum mechanics --the best theory of the infinitesimally small-- with Einstein's general relativity --the best theory of the universe up to its largest distances. He worked with PhD students at NYU and with collaborators in the USA and Switzerland.
Holograms are flat surfaces that produce a three-dimensional image. Many theoretical physicists have conjectured that gravity could also be a "holographic" image of a theory in lower dimensions.  Porrati and collaborators understood certain novel "holographic duals" of gravity. The novelty is that gravity is partially dynamical also on the holographic surface, unlike in previously known cases.
Inflation is the leading paradigm for explaining why the observed universe appears so homogeneous and smooth on very large distances. During inflation the universe underwent a period of faster-than-light expansion at the very beginning of its existence. Supergravity is an extension of Einstein gravity that appears to be as an essential ingredient in many consistent theories of gravity. Finding the ``simplest'' model of inflation in supergravity has proven surprisingly difficult. Porrati and collaborators found such model and studied many of its properties.
Finally, Porrati and his then student Kim applied canonical quantization --a method known since the 1950's-- to the simplest theory of gravity:  gravity in 2D on negatively-curved spaces. By using modern quantization methods and recent results in mathematics they were able to show that canonical quantization defines a very large space of possible dynamical states. Porrati's work suggests that new dynamical symmetries must exist in a mathematically and physically consistent theory of gravity.
Muon capture by protons is a fundamental weak interaction process and has provided an important probe to study nucleon structure.  In 2007, Czarnecki, Marciano and Sirlin introduced electroweak corrections (EWC) in the theory of muon capture and showed that they play a very important role in bringing measurement into good agreement with the theoretical prediction. In order to improve the accuracy of the electroweak corrections, Sirlin studied certain small but important corrections to leading order results. In previous work, Sirlin found that the leading contributions of this class of corrections are proportional to the zeroth order amplitude and, remarkably, cancel among themselves. Recently, Sirlin analyzed the remaining corrections of this class and found that they are negligible at the current and foreseeable levels of experimental precision. In collaboration with Kniehl, Sirlin discussed a generalization of the Dirac equations and spinors in momentum space to unstable spin-1/2 fermions and analyzed their properties. They are very useful in the implementation of renormalization conditions in general theories with intergeneration mixing. Sirlin wrote a paper about Feynman, entitled "Remembering a  Great Teacher". It is a recollection of the memorable experience of attending a 1953 course on Quantum Mechanics given by Feynman in Brasil, and of several meetings and exchanges Sirlin had with him during the following thirty years.
The question why the expansion of the universe is accelerating is an enigmatic one. While vacuum energy can well parametrize the acceleration, it  gives no insights into its origin. Moreover,  the natural value of the vacuum energy  due to particle physics is many orders of magnitude higher than the value one needs to describe  the observed acceleration. Gabadadze has proposed a non-local theory of gravitation that  makes the  vacuum energy nonphysical, and hence irrelevant for the world it describes.
Instead, the accelerated expansion of the universe is due to massive gravitons. Gabadadze and Siqing Yu (NYU grad student) showed that this theory has  concrete predictions, and can be ruled out if future planned observations detect primordial gravitational waves produced in the earliest epoch of the evolution of the universe.
